Because the differences in production between film and television are so basic,
it was not possible to continue work on the development of scripts until the
negotiations with the Office of Education were concluded and a firm contract
amendment assured that it would be possible to produce these materials on film.
This step delayed the schedule for the project by about four months, but there
is no question among all parties concerned that the delay was unavoidable and
will result in a much more useful and effective library of utilization materials.
Between September 15 and the present time, work has proceeded on the develop¬
ment of script treatments and associated materleU-s that would be included with
the kits. A November meeting with the U.S. Office of Education staff and
members of the Project Advisory Committee resulted in helpful suggestions for
modifications of the script treatments, and other meetings of the project
staff have proceeded to the point where most of the filming has already been
done for one of the approved scripts.
During this period, however, oi^ other delay was encountered that makes it
necessary to modify the schedule for the contract. After script treatments
were reviewed by the Project Conanlttee and the Office of Education staff, it
was agreed that instead of further development of the treatments themselves,
the best use of time would be to proceed on the preparation of scripts. A
memorandum from the writer, Mrs. Marye Benjamin, outlined the changes she
Intended to make between the treatment stage and the shooting script stage,
and on this basis it was agreed that the recommended changes could appropriately
be handled within the next phase of the script prepeiration—development of
shooting scripts.
Before shooting scripts could be developed properly, however, it was agreed
that it was necessary to contract with a film producer in order that the
producer and writer could work jointly on the shooting scripts. Because
the film production phase involved a sub-contract between the NAEB and another
organization, this required further negotiation with the Office of Education
which was conducted between January and April, 1964. On February 26, a
specific request from the NAEB asking that a sub-contract be authorized was
submitted to the Office of Education, and on April 23 after further discussion
and evaluation of the NAEB*s request, permission was granted to enter into
such a sub-contract.
Since that time work has been proceeding on schedule with the development of
the films. Script number 5 has been approved by the Office of Education and
will shortly be available for consideration at the "interlock” stage. The
next film to be produced is awaiting final approval of the shooting script,
and should be underway within the next two weeks.
